docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: ''WHAT'S YOUR ASTROLOGICAL sign?'' asks Edna O'Brien over the phone, a friendly but odd question from a serious writer. I can't tell if she thinks this is the standard American get-acquainted question, a fey joke on that, if it's of real interest to her, or a sign of natural dizziness. Cautiously, I reveal myself as a Pisces.
docs.snippet: LEAD: ''WHAT'S YOUR ASTROLOGICAL sign?'' asks Edna O'Brien over the phone, a friendly but odd question from a serious writer. I can't tell if she thinks this is the standard American get-acquainted question, a fey joke on that, if it's of real...

byline.original: By Richard B. Woodward; Richard B. Woodward is an editor and writer who lives in New York

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: I WAS SCARED. I KNEW SOMETHING WAS GONNA HAPPEN,'' HEATH Wilkins recalls. ''My life had become unbearable to me. It was the first time I was out on my own, the first time nobody was responsible for me - see what I'm saying?''
docs.snippet: LEAD: I WAS SCARED. I KNEW SOMETHING WAS GONNA HAPPEN,'' HEATH Wilkins recalls. ''My life had become unbearable to me. It was the first time I was out on my own, the first time nobody was responsible for me - see what I'm saying?''

byline.original: By Ron Rosenbaum: Ron Rosenbaum, a contributing editor of Vanity Fair, is at work on a novel for Viking
